Section 191 (1) BEFORE amended by 2015-22-11(a), effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

(1) If the Board has reasonable grounds for believing that an immediate danger exists that would likely result in serious injury, serious illness or death to a worker, the Board may order

(a) that work at the workplace or any part of the workplace stop until the order to stop work is cancelled by the Board, and

(b) if the Board considers this is necessary, that the workplace or any part of the workplace be cleared of persons and isolated by barricades, fencing or any other means suitable to prevent access to the area until the danger is removed.

Section 191 (1.1) to (1.4) were added by 2015-22-11(a), effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

Section 191 (2) BEFORE amended by 2015-22-11(b), effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

(2) If an order is made under subsection (1) (b), an employer, supervisor or other person must not require or permit a worker to enter the workplace or part of the workplace that is the subject of the order, except for the purpose of doing work that is necessary or required to remove the danger or the hazard and only if the worker

(a) is protected from the danger or the hazard, or

(b) is qualified and properly instructed in how to remedy the unsafe condition with minimum risk to the worker's own health or safety.

Section 196 (6) (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 36/2001 [CPI adj], effective February 23, 2001 (BC Reg 36/2001).

(b) the board must not impose an administrative penalty greater than $510 445.05.

Section 196 (6) (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 200/2001 [CPI adj], effective August 24, 2001 (BC Reg 200/2001).

(b) the board must not impose an administrative penalty greater than $520 435.97.

Section 196 (6) (b) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 274/2001 (157/2001 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2002 (BC Reg 274/2001).

(b) the board must not impose an administrative penalty greater than $528 610.36.

Section 196 (6) (b): January 1, 2002 change is supported by BC Reg 23/2002, effective February 15, 2002 (BC Reg 23/2002).

Section 196 (6) (b): January 1, 2003 change is supported by BC Reg 36/2003, effective January 30, 2003 (BC Reg 36/2003).

(b) the Board must not impose an administrative penalty greater than $530 426.89.

Section 196 BEFORE re-enacted by 2002-66-28, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

(1)  The Board may impose an administrative penalty in accordance with this section if it considers that

(a) an employer has failed to take sufficient precautions for the prevention of work related injuries or illnesses,

(b) an employer has not complied with this Part, the regulations or an applicable order, or

(c) a workplace or working conditions are not safe.

(2)  Before imposing an administrative penalty, the Board must serve a penalty notice on the employer that sets out

(a) the basis on which the administrative penalty is being considered,

(b) the amount of the proposed administrative penalty,

(c) the employer's options to accept the penalty as proposed or to make representations to the Board respecting the proposed penalty or the amount, and

(d) the time limit for giving notice to the Board that the employer intends to make representations referred to in paragraph (c), which must be at least 30 days after the penalty notice is served on the employer.

(3)  On receipt of a penalty notice, the employer must

(a) provide a copy of the notice to the joint committee or worker health and safety representative, as applicable, and

(b) if the workers at the workplace to which the penalty notice relates are represented by a union, send a copy to the union.

(4)  In response to a penalty notice, the employer may

(a) accept the proposed administrative penalty, in which case it is deemed to be an administrative penalty imposed under subsection (6) that is payable as ordered by the Board, or

(b) within the time limit established under subsection (2) (d), notify the Board that the employer wishes to make representations to the Board respecting the matter.

(5)  If an employer has given notice referred to in subsection (4) (b), the Board must give the employer a reasonable time in which to provide information and make other representations to the Board respecting the matter.

(6)  After considering any representations made by the employer under subsection (5) and any other information the Board considers relevant, the Board may, by order, impose an administrative penalty on the employer, subject to the limits that

(a) the employer is not liable to an administrative penalty if the employer proves that the employer exercised due diligence to prevent the failure, non-compliance or conditions to which the penalty relates, and

(b) the Board must not impose an administrative penalty greater than $547 229.80.

(7)  An employer subject to an administrative penalty under this section must pay the amount of the penalty to the Board for deposit into the accident fund.

(8)  If an administrative penalty is reduced or cancelled on appeal, the amount to be returned to the employer must be paid out of the accident fund and must include interest calculated as referred to in section 96 (7).

(9)  If an administrative penalty is imposed on an employer, a prosecution under this Act for the same contravention may not be brought against the employer.

Section 196 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 485/2003 (325/2002 and 216/2003 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2004 (BC Reg 485/2003); supported by BC Reg 24/2004, effective January 23, 2004 (BC Reg 24/2004).

(2)  An administrative penalty which is greater than $500 000 must not be imposed under this section.

(2)  An administrative penalty which is greater than $507 883.82 must not be imposed under this section.

(2)  An administrative penalty which is greater than $519 502.08 must not be imposed under this section.

Section 196 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 225/2014 (247/2013 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2015 (BC Reg 225/2014); supported by BC Reg 32/2015, effective March 3, 2015 (BC Reg 32/2015).

(2) An administrative penalty which is greater than $607 297.58 must not be imposed under this section. [Note: See Note on page 1 of the Act concerning dollar amount.]

Section 196 (1), (3), (6) and (7) BEFORE amended by 2015-22-12, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

(1) The Board may, by order, impose an administrative penalty on an employer under this section if it considers that

(a) the employer has failed to take sufficient precautions for the prevention of work related injuries or illnesses,

(b) the employer has not complied with this Part, the regulations or an applicable order, or

(c) the employer's workplace or working conditions are not safe.

(3) An administrative penalty must not be imposed under this section if an employer exercised due diligence to prevent the circumstances described in subsection (1).

(6) If an administrative penalty under this section is reduced or cancelled by a Board decision, on a review under section 96.2 or on an appeal to the appeal tribunal under Part 4, the Board must

(a) refund the required amount to the employer out of the accident fund, and

(b) pay interest on that amount calculated in accordance with the policies of the board of directors.

(7) If an administrative penalty is imposed on an employer under this section, the employer must not be prosecuted under this Act in respect of the same facts and circumstances upon which the Board based the administrative penalty.

Section 196 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 220/2015 (225/2014 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2016 (BC Reg 220/2015); supported by BC Reg 23/2016, effective February 16, 2016 (BC Reg 23/2016).

(2) An administrative penalty which is greater than $621 615.98 must not be imposed under this section. [Note: See Note on page 1 of the Act concerning dollar amount.]

Section 196 (2) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 241/2019 (247/2018 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2020 (BC Reg 241/2019); supported by BC Reg 46/2020, effective March 2, 2020 (BC Reg 46/2020).

(2) An administrative penalty which is greater than $662 102.49 must not be imposed under this section. [Note: See Note on page 1 of the Act concerning dollar amount.]

Section 196.1 was enacted by 2015-22-13, effective August 4, 2015 (BC Reg 164/2015).

Section 196.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 273/2016 (220/2015 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2017 (BC Reg 273/2016); supported by BC Reg 43/2017, effective February 20, 2017 (BC Reg 43/2017).

(1) The Board may, by order, impose on an employer an administrative penalty prescribed by a regulation of the Board, which penalty must not be more than $1 010.33, if the Board is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the employer has failed to comply with a provision of this Part, or the regulations, as specified by a regulation of the Board.

Section 196.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 211/2017 (273/2016 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2018 (BC Reg 211/2017); supported by BC Reg 19/2018, effective February 20, 2018 (BC Reg 19/2018).

(1) The Board may, by order, impose on an employer an administrative penalty prescribed by a regulation of the Board, which penalty must not be more than $1 025.42, if the Board is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the employer has failed to comply with a provision of this Part, or the regulations, as specified by a regulation of the Board.

Section 196.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 247/2018 (211/2017 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2019 (BC Reg 247/2018); supported by BC Reg 73/2019, effective April 1, 2019 (BC Reg 73/2019).

(1) The Board may, by order, impose on an employer an administrative penalty prescribed by a regulation of the Board, which penalty must not be more than $1 039.72, if the Board is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the employer has failed to comply with a provision of this Part, or the regulations, as specified by a regulation of the Board.

Section 196.1 (1) BEFORE amended by BC Reg 241/2019 (247/2018 rep) [CPI adj], effective January 1, 2020 (BC Reg 241/2019); supported by BC Reg 46/2020, effective March 2, 2020 (BC Reg 46/2020).

(1) The Board may, by order, impose on an employer an administrative penalty prescribed by a regulation of the Board, which penalty must not be more than $1 065.14, if the Board is satisfied on a balance of probabilities that the employer has failed to comply with a provision of this Part, or the regulations, as specified by a regulation of the Board.

Section 197 BEFORE repealed by 2002-66-29, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

Special rules for review of orders in relation to administrative penalties

197 (1)  Once a penalty notice is served under section 196 (2), an order in relation to which the administrative penalty is contemplated may not be reviewed under Division 13 of this Part.

(2)  Despite subsection (1), an order referred to in subsection (1)

(a) may be reviewed in the context of the decision on imposing an administrative penalty if

(i)  a review of the order is underway but has not been completed at the time the penalty notice is served, or

(ii)  the order was made not more than 60 days before the penalty notice was served, and

(b) may be considered in the context of the decision on imposing an administrative penalty, even if the order has previously been reviewed or the time limit under section 201 (1) has expired.

Section 198 (1) BEFORE amended by 2015-22-14, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

(1) On application of the Board and on being satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that a person

(a) has contravened or is likely to contravene this Part, the regulations or an order, or

(b) has not complied or is likely not to comply with this Part, the regulations or an order,

the Supreme Court may grant an injunction restraining the person from continuing or committing the contravention or requiring the person to comply, as applicable.

Section 198 (1.1) and (1.2) were added by 2015-22-14, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

Part 3, Division 13 BEFORE repealed by 2002-66-30, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

Division 13 — Reviews

What decisions are reviewable

199 The following are the decisions that are reviewable under this Division:

(a) an order, other than

(i)  an order under section 196 imposing an administrative penalty, or

(ii)  an order referred to in section 197 (1) that may be considered in the context of deciding whether or not an administrative penalty is to be imposed;

(b) the refusal to make an order that is reviewable under paragraph (a);

(c) the cancellation of an order that is reviewable under paragraph (a);

(d) [Not in force.]

(e) a determination under section 153 (1) respecting discriminatory action or failure to pay wages.

Who may apply for a review

200 An employer, worker, supplier, union or other person aggrieved by a reviewable decision may have the decision reviewed in accordance with this Division.

Applying for a review

201 (1)  In order to have a decision reviewed, the person aggrieved must apply to the Board within 60 days after the date of the decision.

(2)  An application for a review must

(a) be made in writing or in another manner acceptable to the Board,

(b) identify the decision for which a review is requested, and

(c) state the basis on which the application for review is made and the outcome requested.

Board to have application dealt with by reviewing officer

202 (1)  The Board must have an application for review dealt with by a reviewing officer as expeditiously as reasonably practicable after it has been received.

(2)  A review of

(a) a refusal to make an order, if the basis for the application for review is that an order is required to ensure that an unsafe condition is remedied, or

(b) an order under section 195 suspending or cancelling a certificate

must be given priority and dealt with by a reviewing officer as quickly as possible after the application has been received.

(3)  Unless the complexity of the matter makes this impracticable, a decision on the review must be made within 60 days after the application for the review is received by the Board.

(4)  The Board must designate officers to act as reviewing officers for the purposes of this Division, but the reviewing officer in a specific case must not be a person who is the direct supervisor of the officer who made the decision under review.

Generally a review does not operate as a stay

203 (1)  Unless the reviewing officer directs otherwise, a review under this Division does not operate as a stay or suspend the operation of the decision under review.

(2)  The reviewing officer may make a stay or suspension referred to in subsection (1) subject to any conditions the officer specifies.

Notice to other persons

204 (1)  In the case of a review requested by an employer, the employer must

(a) post a notice of the application for review at the workplace to which the decision under review applies,

(b) provide notice of the application to the joint committee or worker representative, as applicable, and

(c) if workers of the employer at that workplace are represented by a union, send notice of the application to the union.

(2)  In the case of a review requested by a worker or union, the worker or union must provide notice of the application for review to the employer, who must give notice in accordance with subsection (1).

(3)  In the case of a review requested by a person other than an employer, worker or union, the person must give notice in accordance with the directions of the reviewing officer.

(4)  As an exception, the requirements of subsection (2) do not apply in relation to an order referred to in section 166 (2).

Review process

205 (1)  Subject to the regulations and this section, the reviewing officer may deal with a review in a manner the officer considers appropriate to the nature and circumstances of the decision being reviewed.

(2)  The applicant requesting a review and an employer, worker or union required to be given notice under section 204 are entitled to present information respecting the review to the reviewing officer.

(3)  Without limiting subsection (1), the reviewing officer may do one or more of the following:

(a) receive any evidence or information on oath, affidavit or otherwise as the officer considers appropriate, whether or not it is admissible as evidence in a court of law;

(b) conduct an inquiry into the matter and consider new information provided by other officers or any other person;

(c) hold a hearing, if the officer is of the opinion that the circumstances justify this;

(d) subject to the entitlement under subsection (2), specify the persons or organizations who may participate in a review and the manner in which they may participate;

(e) require the applicant or other parties to provide further information.

Decision on review

206 (1)  In dealing with a review, the reviewing officer may confirm, vary or cancel the decision under review or substitute his or her own decision for the decision under review.

(2)  The reviewing officer must provide a written copy of his or her decision on the review, with reasons, to

(a) the applicant for the review, and

(b) any other parties who participated in the review.

(3)  If the decision on a review is in relation to an order that was required by or under this Act to be posted by an employer at a workplace, the reviewing officer must provide a copy of the decision to the employer, who must then post it at the workplace.

(4)  Subject to the authority of the Board under section 113 (2) or an appeal under Division 14 of this Part, a decision of a reviewing officer on any matter in which the reviewing officer has jurisdiction under this Division is final and conclusive and is not open to question or review in a court on any grounds.

Part 3, Division 14 BEFORE repealed by 2002-16-30, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

Division 14 — Appeals

What decisions are appealable to appeal tribunal

207 The following are decisions that may be appealed to the appeal tribunal in accordance with this Division:

(a) in relation to administrative penalties under section 196,

(i)  an order imposing an administrative penalty,

(ii)  the cancellation of an order imposing an administrative penalty, or

(iii)  a decision not to impose an administrative penalty made after issuing a penalty notice under section 196 (2);

(b) a decision on a review under Division 13 of this Part in relation to a determination or order under section 153, including a decision respecting the refusal to make or the cancellation of an order under that section;

(c) a decision on a review under Division 13 of this Part in relation to an order under section 195;

(d) any other decision under this Part or the regulations that is prescribed by regulation to be an appealable decision.

Who may bring an appeal

208 The following may bring an appeal of an appealable decision:

(a) for an appeal in relation to an administrative penalty,

(i)  the employer subject to the penalty, unless the employer accepted the penalty under section 196 (4) (a),

(ii)  a worker of the employer or a union representing workers of the employer, or

(iii)  any other person aggrieved by the decision;

(b) for an appeal in relation to a decision under section 153, the worker, employer or union affected by the decision;

(c) for an appeal in relation to an order under section 195, the person subject to the order;

(d) for an appeal in relation to a decision prescribed to be appealable, the persons permitted by regulation to appeal.

Applying for an appeal

209 (1)  In order to bring an appeal under this Division, a person must apply in writing to the appeal tribunal within 30 days of the decision being appealed.

(2)  An application under subsection (1) must

(a) identify the decision that is the subject of the application for appeal,

(b) state the basis on which the application for an appeal is made and the outcome requested, and

(c) include any other information required by the appeal tribunal.

Generally an appeal does not operate as a stay

210 (1)  Unless the appeal tribunal directs otherwise, an appeal does not operate as a stay or suspend the operation of the decision under appeal.

(2)  The appeal tribunal may make a stay or suspension referred to in subsection (1) subject to any conditions it specifies.

Appeal process

211 (1)  Subject to this Division, sections 85.1, 85.2 and 87 apply for the purposes of an appeal under this Division.

(2)  In the case of an appeal by an employer, worker or union, notice of the appeal application must be given in accordance with section 204 (1) and (2).

(3)  In the case of an appeal by a person other than an employer, worker or union, the person must give notice in accordance with the directions of the appeal tribunal.

(4)  For certainty, section 96.1 does not apply to an appeal under this Division.

Decision on an appeal

212 (1)  After considering the appeal, the appeal tribunal may

(a) confirm, vary or cancel the decision under appeal, or

(b) refer the matter back to the Board for reconsideration.

(2)  The appeal tribunal must make a written copy of its decision, with reasons, available to

(a) the applicant for the appeal, and

(b) any other parties who participated in the appeal.

(3)  A decision of the appeal tribunal on any matter in which it has jurisdiction is final and conclusive and is not open to question or review in a court on any grounds.

Section 221 BEFORE re-enacted by 2002-66-31, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

221 (1)  A notice, order or other document that is required to be served on or otherwise sent to a person under this Part is deemed to have been served if

(a) it is personally served on the person, or

(b) it is sent by registered mail to the person's last known address.

(2)  If service is by registered mail, the document is deemed to be served on the person on the eighth day after it is deposited in a Canada Post Office.

(3)  At the request of a person on whom a document is required to be served, the document may be transmitted to the person electronically or by fax machine.

(4)  A document transmitted under subsection (3) is deemed to have been served when the person serving the document receives an acknowledgment of the transmission from the person served.

Section 221 (4), (5) and (6) were added by 2004-45-174, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 224 (2) (k) BEFORE amended by 2002-56-40, effective June 30, 2002 (BC Reg 152/2002).

(k) amending the Act to reflect the deemed amendments under section 25 (4);

Section 224 (2) (j) BEFORE amended by 2002-66-32(a), effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

(j) prescribing a type of decision under this Part or the regulations as being appealable under Division 14 of this Part and prescribing who may bring an appeal of such a decision;

Section 224 (2) (k.1) to (k.3) was added by 2002-66-32(b), effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

Section 224 (2) (k) BEFORE amended by 2003-65-26, effective December 31, 2003 (BC Reg 417/2003).

(k) amending the Act to reflect the deemed amendments under sections 25.2 and 25.3;

Section 224 (2) (j) BEFORE amended by 2007-14-215,Sch, effective December 1, 2007 (BC Reg 354/2007).

(j) prescribing any decisions or orders under this Act or the regulations that may be appealed to the appeal tribunal under Part 4, prescribing who may appeal those decisions or orders and prescribing classes of decisions for purposes of section 239 (2) (a);

Section 225 (2) (f.1) was added by 2015-22-15, effective August 4, 2015 (BC Reg 164/2015).

Part 4 was added by 2002-66-33, effective March 3, 2003 (BC Reg 320/2002).

Section 231 definition "worker" was added by 2004-23-37, effective June 15, 2004 (BC Reg 212/2004).

Section 232 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-64(a), effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(2)  The appeal tribunal consists of the following members:

Section 232 (3) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-64(b), effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(3)  The chair holds office for a term of up to 5 years and may be reappointed for one or more successive terms of up to 5 years each.

Section 232 (4) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-64(c), effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(4)  The vice chairs hold office in their first term for 2 years and may be reappointed for one or more successive terms of up to 4 years each.

Section 232 (6) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-64(d), effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(6)  Individuals are not eligible for appointment as vice chairs unless they have successfully completed a competency-based selection process established or approved by the chair.

Section 232 (10) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-64(e), effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(10)  Despite subsections (3) to (5), if a member of the appeal tribunal is absent or incapacitated,

(a) the Lieutenant Governor in Council, if the member is the chair, or

(b) the chair, if the member is a vice chair or extraordinary member,

may appoint a temporary substitute member to act during the absence or incapacity.

Section 232 (7) BEFORE repealed by 2004-45-175, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(7)  All members of the appeal tribunal must perform their duties and functions in a fair, impartial and expeditious manner.

Section 232 (10) BEFORE amended by 2007-14-67, effective October 18, 2007 (BC Reg 311/2007).

(10)  Despite subsections (3) to (5), if a member of the appeal tribunal is absent or incapacitated,

(a) the Lieutenant Governor in Council, if the member is the chair, or

(b) the chair, if the member is a vice chair or extraordinary member,

may appoint a person, who would otherwise be qualified for appointment as a member, as a temporary substitute member to act during the absence or incapacity.

Section 232 (11) was added by 2007-14-67, effective October 18, 2007 (BC Reg 311/2007).

Section 232 (2), (3), (4) and (6) BEFORE amended by 2015-10-198, effective December 18, 2015 (BC Reg 240/2015).

(2) The appeal tribunal consists of the following members appointed after a merit based process:

(a) the chair appointed by the Lieutenant Governor in Council;

(b) one or more vice chairs appointed by the chair, after consultation with the minister;

(c) any extraordinary members appointed by the chair, after consultation with the minister, with representation from individuals with experience in employers' interests and from individuals with experience in workers' interests.

(3) The chair holds office for an initial term of 3 to 5 years and may be reappointed for one or more successive terms of up to 5 years each.

(4) The vice chairs hold office for an initial term of 2 to 4 years and may be reappointed for additional terms of up to 5 years.

(6) Individuals are not eligible for appointment as vice chairs unless they have successfully completed a merit based process established or approved by the chair.

Section 233 (2) BEFORE amended by 2003-47-65, effective February 13, 2004 (BC Reg 45/2004).

(2)  A member of the appeal tribunal who resigns or whose appointment has expired may continue to exercise his or her powers in an appeal on which that member is sitting until a decision is made on that appeal.

Section 233 (3) and (4) were added by 2015-10-199, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

Section 234 (2) (d) and (e) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-176, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(d) establishing any rules, forms, practices and procedures required for the efficient and cost effective conduct of appeals to the appeal tribunal, including

(i)  establishing time periods within which steps must be taken,

(ii)  requiring pre-hearing conferences, and

(iii)  employing voluntary alternate dispute resolution processes;

(e) making accessible to the public any rules, forms, practices and procedures established under paragraph (d);

Section 235 (2) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-177, effective March 3, 2003 [retro from May 20, 2004 (Royal Assent)].

(2)  The Pension (Public Service) Act and the Public Service Benefits Plan Act apply to the employees of the appeal tribunal.

Section 236 (5) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-178(part), effective March 3, 2003 [retro from May 20, 2004 (Royal Assent)].

NOTE: this version of subsection (5) remains in act until the remainder of section 236 is in force.

(5)  Subject to subsection (4), the minister may establish the conditions of appointment of the members of the appeal tribunal.

Section 236 (1) to (4) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-178(rem), effective July 8, 2004 (BC Reg 314/2004).

NOTE: the above version of subsection (5) deleted in act as a result of the remainder of section 236 (1) to (4) coming into force (see below).

236 (1)  All members of the appeal tribunal must be compensated in accordance with the regulation made under subsection (2).

(2)  For the purposes of subsection (1), the minister may make a regulation respecting the compensation of members of the appeal tribunal, including specifying different rates of compensation for different classes of members.

(3)  All members of the appeal tribunal must be reimbursed for reasonable travelling and out of pocket expenses necessarily incurred by them in performing their duties.

(4)  The Pension (Public Service) Act and the Public Service Benefits Plan Act apply to the members of the appeal tribunal.

Section 238 (11) was added by 2004-45-179, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 241 (6) was added by 2004-23-38, effective June 15, 2004 (BC Reg 212/2004).

Section 242 (2) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-180, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(2)  A notice of appeal must

(a) be made in writing or in another form acceptable to the appeal tribunal,

(b) identify the decision or order that is being appealed,

(c) state why the decision or order is incorrect or why it should be changed, and

(d) state the outcome requested.

Section 242 (3) was added by 2004-45-180, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 244 BEFORE amended by 2004-45-181, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

244 Unless the chair directs otherwise, the filing of a notice of appeal under section 242 does not operate as a stay or affect the operation of the decision or order under appeal.

Section 244.1 was enacted by 2004-23-39, effective June 15, 2004 (BC Reg 212/2004).

Section 245.1 was enacted by 2004-45-182, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 245.1 BEFORE amended by 2007-14-68, effective October 18, 2007 (BC Reg 311/2007).

245.1 Sections 1, 11, 13 to 15, 28 to 32, 35 (1) to (3), 37, 38, 42, 44, 48, 49, 52, 55 to 58, 60 (a) and (b) and 61 of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the appeal tribunal.

Section 245.1 BEFORE re-enacted by 2015-10-200, effective December 18, 2015 (BC Reg 240/2015).

Application of Administrative Tribunals Act to appeal tribunal proceedings

245.1 Sections 1, 11, 13 to 15, 28 to 32, 35 (1) to (3), 37, 38, 42, 44, 46.3, 48, 49, 52, 55 to 58, 60 (a) and (b) and 61 of the Administrative Tribunals Act apply to the appeal tribunal.

Section 246 (1) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-183(a), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(1)  Subject to any rules, practices or procedures established by the chair, the appeal tribunal may conduct an appeal in the manner it considers necessary, including conducting hearings in writing or orally with the parties present in person or by means of teleconference or videoconference facilities.

Section 246 (2) (a) and (b) BEFORE repealed by 2004-45-183(b), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(a) receive evidence or information on oath, by affidavit or otherwise, as it considers appropriate, whether or not the evidence is admissible in a court;

(b) receive new evidence;

Section 246 (5) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-183(b), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(5)  If, in an appeal, a party fails to comply with the procedures of the appeal tribunal including any time limits specified for taking any actions, the tribunal may, after giving notice to that party,

(a) continue with the proceedings and make a decision based upon the evidence before it, or

(b) determine that the appeal has been abandoned.

Section 246.1 was enacted by 2004-45-184, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 247 (1) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-185(a), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(1)  On an appeal, the appeal tribunal has the same powers as the Supreme Court

(a) to compel the attendance of witnesses and examine them under oath, and

(b) to compel the production and inspection of books, papers, documents and things.

Section 247 (1.1) was added by 2004-45-185(a), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 247 (3) and (4) BEFORE amended by 2004-45-185(b), effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

(3)  Despite subsections (1) and (2), an officer, an employee or a contractor of the Board may only be compelled to give evidence or produce books, papers, documents and things that

(a) relate to the issues in a specific appeal, and

(b) are necessary for the appeal tribunal to address those issues and to make a decision in the appeal.

(4)  Despite subsections (1) and (2), a member of the board of directors or an officer, an employee or a contractor of the Board may not be compelled to give evidence or produce books, papers, documents and things respecting the development or adoption of the policies of the board of directors.

Section 247 (2) BEFORE amended by 2010-6-97,Sch 7, effective July 1, 2010.

(2)  On an appeal, the appeal tribunal may cause depositions of witnesses residing in or out of the Province to be taken before a person appointed by the appeal tribunal in a similar manner to that prescribed by the Rules of Court for the taking of like depositions in the Supreme Court before a commissioner.

Section 249 (5) (b) BEFORE amended by 2004-23-40, effective May 14, 2004 (BC Reg 212/2004).

(b) is treating or has previously treated the worker or a member of the worker's family,

Section 250 (3) BEFORE amended by 2015-10-201, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

Section 250 (3.1) was added by 2015-10-201, effective May 14, 2015 (Royal Assent).

Section 253.1 was enacted by 2004-45-186, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 254 BEFORE amended by 2004-45-187, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

The appeal tribunal has exclusive jurisdiction to inquire into, hear and determine all those matters and questions of fact and law arising or required to be determined under this Part, including the following:

Section 255 (4) and (5) were added by 2004-45-188, effective December 3, 2004 (BC Reg 516/2004).

Section 257 (2) (a) BEFORE amended by 2004-23-41, effective June 15, 2004 (BC Reg 212/2004).

(a) a person was, at the time the cause of action arose, a worker within the meaning of Part 1,

Schedule B heading BEFORE amended by 2002-56-41, effective June 30, 2002 (BC Reg 152/2002).

Schedule B

(Section 6 (4))

Schedule B BEFORE amended by 2002-56-43, effective June 30, 2002 (BC Reg 152/2002).

(ii) continued to be free from evidence of tuberculosis for 6 months after being so employed (except in primary tuberculosis as proven by a negative tuberculin test at time of employment). In the case of an employee previously compensated for tuberculosis, any subsequent tuberculosis after the disease has become inactive and has remained inactive for a period of 3 years or more shall not be deemed to have occurred as a result of the original disability for the purpose of the Act, unless the worker is still engaged in employment listed above or the board is satisfied that the subsequent tuberculosis is the direct result of the tuberculosis for which the worker has been compensated.

Schedule B, item 4 paragraph (a) BEFORE deleted by BC Reg 224/2010 under RS1996-492-6(4.1), effective September 28, 2010 [90 days after BC Reg 224/2010 deposited 30 June 2010] (BC Reg 224/2010).

(a) Carcinoma of the lung when associated with:
(i) asbestosis or Where there is exposure to airborne asbestos dust.
(ii) bilateral diffuse pleural thickening or fibrosis, over 5 mm thick and extending over more than a quarter of the chest wall Where there is exposure to airborne asbestos dust and the claimant has not previously suffered collagen disease, chronic uremia, drug-induced fibrosis, tuberculosis or other infection or trauma capable of causing pleural thickening or fibrosis.

Schedule B, item 4 paragraphs (a.1) and (a.2) were added by BC Reg 224/2010 under RS1996-492-6(4.1), effective September 28, 2010 [90 days after BC Reg 224/2010 deposited 30 June 2010] (BC Reg 224/2010).

Schedule B, items 3A, 3B, 12, 13, and 16 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 224/2010 under RS1996-492-6(4.1), effective March 1, 2015 (BC Reg 224/2010).

Schedule B

Description of Disease Description of Process or Industry
3A Diffuse pleural thickening or fibrosis, whether unilateral or bilateral Where there is exposure to airborne asbestos dust and the claimant has not previously suffered and is not currently suffering collagen disease, chronic uremia, drug-induced fibrosis, tuberculosis or other infection, trauma, or disease capable of causing pleural thickening or fibrosis.
3B Benign pleural effusion, whether unilateral or bilateral Where there is exposure to airborne asbestos dust and the claimant has not previously suffered and is not currently suffering collagen disease, chronic uremia, tuberculosis or other infection, trauma, or disease capable of causing pleural effusion.
12 Bursitis:
(a) Knee bursitis (inflammation of the prepatellar, suprapatellar, or superficial infrapatellar bursa) Where there is repeated jarring impact against, or where there are significant periods of kneeling on, the affected knee.
(b) Shoulder bursitis (inflammation of the subacromial or subdeltoid bursa) Where there is frequently repeated or sustained abduction or flexion of the shoulder joint greater than sixty degrees and where such activity represents a significant component of the employment.
13 Tendinitis, tenosynovitis:
(a) Hand-wrist tendinitis, tenosynovitis (including deQuervain's tenosynovitis) Where there is use of the affected tendon(s) to perform a task or series of tasks that involves any two of the following:
(1) frequently repeated motions or muscle contractions that place strain on the affected tendon(s);
(2) significant flexion, extension, ulnar deviation or radial deviation of the affected hand or wrist;
(3) forceful exertion of the muscles utilized in handling or moving tools or other objects with the affected hand or wrist;
and where such activity represents a significant component of the employment.
(b) Shoulder tendinitis Where there is frequently repeated or sustained abduction or flexion of the shoulder joint greater than sixty degrees and where such activity represents a significant component of the employment.
16 Hand or arm vibration syndrome Where there have been at least 1 000 hours of exposure to tools or equipment which cause the transfer of significant vibration to the hand or arm of the claimant.

Schedule B, item 6 BEFORE amended by BC Reg 212/2017 under RS1996-492-6(4.1), effective March 1, 2018 (BC Reg 212/2017).

Description of Disease Description of Process or Industry
6 Asthma Where there is exposure to
(1) western red cedar dust; or
(2) isocyanate vapours or gases; or
(3) the dust, fume of vapours of other chemicals or organic material known to cause asthma.

Schedule D BEFORE amended by 2002-56-43, effective June 30, 2002 (BC Reg 152/2002).

The loss of hearing in decibels in the first column is the arithmetic average of thresholds of hearing measured in each ear in turn by pure tone, air conduction audiometry at frequencies of 500, 1 000 and 2 000 Hertzian waves, the measurements being made with an audiometer calibrated according to standards prescribed by the board.

Consumer Price Index Adjustments, BC Reg 224/2011 [CPI adj] BEFORE repealed and replaced by BC Reg 389/2012, effective January 1, 2013 (BC Reg 389/2012).

B.C. Reg. 224/2011 , deposited December 5, 2011, pursuant to the WORKERS COMPENSATION ACT [sections 25 and 25.2]. Regulation of the Workers' Compensation Board, dated November 28, 2011.

CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ADJUSTMENTS

WHEREAS sections 25 and 25.2 of the Workers Compensation Act ("Act") requires the Board to determine as of January 1, 2012, a percentage change by comparing the Consumer Price Index for October 2011 with the Consumer Price Index for October 2010 and by applying that percentage change to adjust those periodic payments of compensation referred to in section 25 (3), and to adjust dollar amounts in the Act referred to in section 25.2 (1);

AND WHEREAS the Board is advised that the Consumer Price Index for October 2010 was 117.4 and for October 2011 was 120.8 giving a percentage change of 2.896082% and subtracting 1% gives a percentage change of 1.896082%;

AND WHEREAS section 25 (2) requires that the percentage resulting from calculations made under section 25 (1), for purposes of section 25 (3), must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%;

AND WHEREAS B.C. Reg. 365/2010 amended dollar amounts described in section 25.2 (1) as of January 1, 2011 as shown in column 1 below;

THE BOARD HEREBY DETERMINES THAT B.C. Reg. 365/2010 shall be repealed as of January 1, 2012;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (1) (b) is 1.896082%;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (2) is 1.896082%;

AND THAT all periodic payments of compensation described in section 25 (3) shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 1.896082% as of January 1, 2012;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25.2 (1) is 2.896082%;

AND THAT all dollar amounts referred to in section 25.2 (1) of the Act shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 2.896082% as of January 1, 2012, as follows:

January 1, 2011
Dollar
Amount 		January 1, 2012
Dollar Amount

17 (3) (a) (ii) 319.05 328.29
17 (3) (c) 1,030.98 1,060.84
17 (3) (d) 1,030.98 1,060.84
17 (3) (f) (iii) (B) 319.05 328.29
17 (3) (g) 34,371.71 35,367.14
17 (3) (h) (i) 564.67 581.02

AND pursuant to section 25.2 (2), all sections containing such dollar amounts shall be deemed to be amended accordingly as of January 1, 2012.

— By The Board, David Anderson, President and CEO, Workers' Compensation Board .

Consumer Price Index Adjustments, BC Reg 389/2012 [CPI adj] BEFORE repealed and replaced by BC Reg 247/2013, effective January 1, 2014 (BC Reg 247/2013).

B.C. Reg. 389/2012 , deposited December 6, 2012, pursuant to the WORKERS COMPENSATION ACT [sections 25 and 25.2]. Resolution of the Workers' Compensation Board, dated November 29, 2012.

CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ADJUSTMENTS

WHEREAS sections 25 and 25.2 of the Workers Compensation Act ("Act") requires the Board to determine as of January 1, 2013, a percentage change by comparing the Consumer Price Index for October 2012 with the Consumer Price Index for October 2011 and by applying that percentage change to adjust those periodic payments of compensation referred to in section 25 (3), and to adjust dollar amounts in the Act referred to in section 25.2 (1);

AND WHEREAS the Board is advised that the Consumer Price Index for October 2011 was 120.8 and for October 2012 was 122.2 giving a percentage change of 1.158940% and subtracting 1% gives a percentage change of 0.158940%;

AND WHEREAS section 25 (2) requires that the percentage resulting from calculations made under section 25 (1), for purposes of section 25 (3), must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%;

AND WHEREAS B.C. Reg. 224/2011 amended dollar amounts described in section 25.2 (1) as of January 1, 2012 as shown in column 1 below;

THE BOARD HEREBY DETERMINES THAT B.C. Reg. 224/2011 shall be repealed as of January 1, 2013;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (1) (b) is 0.158940%;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (2) is 0.158940%;

AND THAT all periodic payments of compensation described in section 25 (3) shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 0.158940% as of January 1, 2013;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25.2 (1) is 1.158940%;

AND THAT all dollar amounts referred to in section 25.2 (1) of the Act, shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 1.158940% as of January 1, 2013 as follows:

Column 1 Column 2

AND pursuant to section 25.2 (2), all sections containing such dollar amounts shall be deemed to be amended accordingly as of January 1, 2013.

— By The Board, D. Anderson, President and CEO, Workers' Compensation Board.

Consumer Price Index Adjustments, BC Reg 247/2013 [CPI adj] BEFORE repealed and replaced by BC Reg 225/2014, effective January 1, 2015 (BC Reg 225/2014).

Schedule [CPI adj]

B.C. Reg. 247/2013 , deposited December 2, 2013, pursuant to the WORKERS COMPENSATION ACT [sections 25 and 25.2]. Resolution of the Workers' Compensation Board, dated November 27, 2013.

CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ADJUSTMENTS

WHEREAS sections 25 and 25.2 of the Workers Compensation Act (" Act ") requires the Board to determine as of January 1, 2014, a percentage change by comparing the Consumer Price Index for October 2013 with the Consumer Price Index for October 2012 and by applying that percentage change to adjust those periodic payments of compensation referred to in section 25(3), and to adjust dollar amounts in the Act referred to in section 25.2(1);

AND WHEREAS the Board is advised that the Consumer Price Index for October 2012 was 122.2 and for October 2013 was 123.0 giving a percentage change of 0.654664% and subtracting 1% gives a percentage change of -0.345336%;

AND WHEREAS section 25(2) requires that the percentage resulting from calculations made under section 25(1), for purposes of section 25(3), must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%;

AND WHEREAS B.C. Reg. 389/2012 amended dollar amounts described in section 25.2(1) as of January 1, 2013 as shown in column 1 below;

THE BOARD HEREBY DETERMINES THAT B.C. Reg. 389/2012 shall be repealed as of January 1, 2014;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25(1)(b) is 0.0%;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25(2) is 0.0%;

AND THAT all periodic payments of compensation described in section 25(3) shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 0% as of January 1, 2014;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25.2(1) is 0.654664%;

AND THAT all dollar amounts referred to in section 25.2(1) of the Act , shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 0.654664% as of January 1, 2014 as follows:

Consumer Price Index Adjustments, BC Reg 225/2014 [CPI adj] BEFORE repealed and replaced by BC Reg 220/2015, effective January 1, 2016 (BC Reg 220/2015).

Schedule [CPI adj]

B.C. Reg. 225/2014 , deposited December 2, 2014, pursuant to the WORKERS COMPENSATION ACT [sections 25 and 25.2]. Resolution of the Workers' Compensation Board, dated November 28, 2014.

CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ADJUSTMENTS

WHEREAS sections 25 and 25.2 of the Workers Compensation Act (" Act ") requires the Board to determine, as of January 1, 2015, a percentage change by comparing the Consumer Price Index for October 2014 with the Consumer Price Index for October 2013, and, by applying that percentage change to adjust those periodic payments of compensation referred to in section 25 (3), and to adjust the dollar amounts in the Act referred to in section 25.2 (1);

AND WHEREAS the Board is advised that the Consumer Price Index for October 2013 was 123.0 and for October 2014 was 125.9, giving a percentage change of 2.357724%, and, after subtracting 1%, giving a percentage change of 1.357724%;

AND WHEREAS section 25 (2) requires that the percentage resulting from calculations made under section 25 (1), for the purposes of section 25 (3), must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%;

AND WHEREAS B.C. Reg. 247/2013 amended the dollar amounts described in section 25.2 (1) as of January 1, 2014, as shown in column 1 below;

THE BOARD HEREBY DETERMINES THAT B.C. Reg. 247/2013 shall be repealed as of January 1, 2015;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (1) (b) is 1.357724%;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (2) is 1.357724%;

AND THAT all periodic payments of compensation described in section 25 (3) shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 1.357724% as of January 1, 2015;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25.2 (1) is 2.357724%;

AND THAT all dollar amounts referred to in section 25.2 (1) of the Act shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 2.357724% as of January 1, 2015 as follows:

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (2) is 0.032566%;

Consumer Price Index Adjustments, BC Reg 273/2016 [CPI adj] BEFORE repealed and replaced by BC Reg 211/2017, effective January 1, 2018 (BC Reg 211/2017).

CPI Adjustments

B.C. Reg. 273/2016 , deposited November 24, 2016, pursuant to the WORKERS COMPENSATION ACT [sections 25 and 25.2]. Resolution of the Workers' Compensation Board, dated November 24, 2015.

CONSUMER PRICE INDEX ADJUSTMENTS

WHEREAS sections 25 and 25.2 of the Workers Compensation Act (" Act ") requires the Board to determine as of January 1, 2017, a percentage change by comparing the Consumer Price Index for October 2016 with the Consumer Price Index for October 2015 and by applying that percentage change to adjust those periodic payments of compensation referred to in section 25 (3), and to adjust dollar amounts in the Act referred to in section 25.2 (1);

AND WHEREAS the Board is advised that the Consumer Price Index for October 2015 was 127.2 and for October 2016 was 129.1, giving a percentage change of 1.493711% and subtracting 1% gives a percentage change of 0.493711%;

AND WHEREAS section 25 (2) requires that the percentage resulting from calculations made under section 25 (1), for purposes of section 25 (3), must not be greater than 4% or less than 0%;

AND WHEREAS B.C. Reg. 220/2015 amended dollar amounts described in section 25.2 (1) as of January 1, 2016 as shown in column 1 below;

THE BOARD HEREBY DETERMINES THAT B.C. Reg. 220/2015 shall be repealed as of January 1, 2017;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (1) (b) is 0.493711%;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25 (2) is 0.493711%;

AND THAT all periodic payments of compensation described in section 25 (3) shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 0.493711% as of January 1, 2017;

AND THAT the percentage change applicable under section 25.2 (1) is 1.493711%;

AND THAT all dollar amounts referred to in section 25.2 (1) of the Act , shall be adjusted by applying the percentage change of 1.493711% as of January 1, 2017 as follows:

Schedule [CPI adj]

The Workers' Compensation Board orders that, effective January 1, 2018,

(a) the dollar amounts referred to in the Workers Compensation Act set out in column 2 of the attached Schedule are adjusted, in accordance with section 25.2 (1) of the Act, to the dollar amounts set out in column 3 of the attached Schedule, and

(b) B.C. Reg. 273/2016 is repealed.

— D. MILES, President, Workers' Compensation Board .
